metadata.titleEn: Arctic Snow Water Equivalent Grid Dataset (1979-2019)
metadata.description: Snow water equivalent (SWE) is an important parameter of the surface hydrological model and climate model. The data is based on the ridge regression algorithm of machine learning, which integrates a variety of existing snow water equivalent data products to form a set of snow water equivalent data products with continuous time series and high accuracy. The spatial range of the data is Pan-Arctic (45 N° to 90 N °), The data time series is 1979-2019. The dataset is expected to provide more accurate snow water equivalent data for the hydrological and climate model, and provide data support for cryosphere change and global change.
metadata.instructions:
File name: snow water equivalent data is stored in NetCDF format, and the file name is "Arctic_SWE_yyyy.nc ", where yyyy stands for the year, such as Arctic_SWE_1979.nc represents the daily grid snow water equivalent dataset in 1979 described in this NetCDF file.
The data reading mode: the data set can be viewed by using Panoply or PyNcView software, and can be processed by using Linux CDO command line tool, or Python netCDF4 library and xarray library.

background: The snow water equivalent (SWE) is an important parameter of surface hydrological and climate systems, and it has a profound impact on Arctic amplification and climate change. In most land areas of the Northern Hemisphere, annual runoff is dominated by snowmelt, and accurately estimating the impacts of such a large amount of snowmelt runoff on ecosystems and human activities is of great significance. At present, there are many forms of SWE data in the world. However, the time ranges of AMSR-E and AMSR-E2 SWE are only from 2003 to the present, which is lacking in terms of time series. Although the reanalysis SWE data have good spatial and temporal continuity and high data integrity, their accuracy is poor, and the mean absolute error (MAE) is 0.65. There are great differences among remote sensing SWE, reanalysis SWE data, data assimilation SWE, and observational SWE. In summary, although there are a variety of SWE data in the world, the data quality is uncertain. Previous studies have shown that all kinds of SWE data in the Northern Hemisphere have advantages and disadvantages, and none of these data perform well in all aspects. Many scholars have conducted in-depth studies on SWE data fusion. Studies have shown that even the simplest multisource data average is more accurate than a single SWE product. In summary, based on the existing SWE data products, combining a machine learning algorithm to fuse multisource SWE data is an effective method to prepare SWE products with long time series and large spatial scales and retain the advantages of single SWE data products.
research objective: In this study, utilizing the ridge regression model (RRM) of a machine learning algorithm, we integrated various existing SWE products to generate a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision RRM SWE product. The RRM SWE product is expected to provide more accurate SWE data for the hydrological model and climate model and provide data support for cryosphere change and climate change studies.
challenges: However, there are great differences among existing SWE products. The time ranges of AMSR-E and AMSR-E2 SWE are only from 2003 to the present, which is lacking in terms of time series. Although the reanalysis SWE data have good spatial and temporal continuity and high data integrity, their accuracy is poor, and the mean absolute error (MAE) is 0.65. The SWE data from stations and meteorological observations cannot meet the needs of hydrometeorological and climate change research. There are great differences among remote sensing SWE, reanalysis SWE data, data assimilation SWE, and observational SWE.
methods: In this study, we utilized ERA-Interim SWE data, GLDAS SWE data, GlobSnow SWE data, AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE data, and ERA5-Land SWE data as the original input datasets for the fusion data. In this study, we utilize the ridge regression model of a machine learning algorithm to fuse ERA-Interim SWE data, GLDAS SWE data, GlobSnow SWE data, AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE data, and ERA5-Land SWE data to generate a set of new RRM SWE datasets.
dataset: In this study, we utilized ERA-Interim SWE data (Dee et al., 2011), GLDAS SWE data (Rodell et al., 2004), GlobSnow SWE data (Luojus et al., 2021), AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE data (Tedesco and Jeyaratnam, 2019), and ERA5-Land SWE data (Muñoz Sabater, 2019) as the original input datasets for the fusion data. The spatial resolution of the AMSR-E SWE and AMSR2 SWE datasets is 25 km×25 km, the temporal resolution is daily, and the data formats are HDF-EOS and HDF-EOS5, respectively. This assimilation system includes data with spatial resolutions of 1◦×1◦and 0.25◦× 0.25◦and temporal resolutions of 3 h, 1 d, and 1 month. The GLDAS data are available for download from the Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center (GES DISC). We obtain an SWE dataset with a daily temporal resolution, 0.25◦spatial resolution, and netCDF4 data format.
findings: The results show that it is feasible to utilize a ridge regression model based on a machine learning algorithm to prepare SWE products on a global scale. The accuracy of the RRM SWE dataset is improved by 28 %, 22 %, 37 %, 11 %, and 11 % compared with the original AMSR-E/AMSR2 (SWE), ERA-Interim SWE, Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS) SWE, GlobSnow SWE, and ERA5-Land SWE datasets, respectively, and it has a higher spatial resolution. The RRM SWE product production method does not rely heavily on an independent SWE product; it takes full advantage of each SWE dataset, and it takes into consideration the altitude factor. This method has good stability, is extremely suitable for the production of snow datasets with large spatial scales, and can be easily extended to the preparation of other snow datasets.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how machine learning algorithms are used to improve the accuracy of snow water equivalent datasets?
Example.Answer: In the field of snow water equivalent data collection, ridge regression, a type of machine learning algorithm, is used to fuse various existing SWE datasets, such as ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and ERA5-Land, to produce a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision dataset. This approach improves the accuracy by taking advantage of each dataset's strengths and incorporating factors like altitude.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of the challenges faced when integrating multiple snow water equivalent datasets?
Example.Answer: An example of the challenges in integrating multiple snow water equivalent datasets includes the significant differences among existing SWE products, such as remote sensing SWE, reanalysis SWE data, data assimilation SWE, and observational SWE. Each has varying time ranges and accuracy, with reanalysis SWE data having a mean absolute error of 0.65, necessitating advanced methods like machine learning for effective fusion.

These datasets offer varying spatial resolutions, such as 25 km×25 km for AMSR-E/AMSR2, and temporal resolutions, like daily updates.

Definition.Question: What is the definition of 'snow water equivalent (SWE)' in the context of hydrological and climate models?
Definition.Answer: Snow water equivalent (SWE) is an important parameter of surface hydrological and climate systems, representing the amount of water contained within snowpack. It is crucial for accurate modeling of snowmelt runoff, which influences ecosystems and human activities, particularly in regions where annual runoff is dominated by snowmelt.

Definition.Question: How is ridge regression used as a machine learning algorithm in the context of SWE data fusion?
Definition.Answer: Ridge regression is utilized as a machine learning algorithm to combine multiple existing SWE datasets, generating a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision SWE product. This approach enhances accuracy by taking advantage of each dataset's strengths and considers factors like altitude, without heavily relying on any single SWE product.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the data formats and temporal resolutions of the AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE datasets compared to the GLDAS SWE datasets?
Comparison.Answer: AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE datasets have a spatial resolution of 25 km×25 km, a daily temporal resolution, and are formatted in HDF-EOS and HDF-EOS5. In contrast, GLDAS SWE datasets have spatial resolutions of 1°×1° and 0.25°×0.25°, temporal resolutions of 3 hours, 1 day, and 1 month, and are available in a netCDF4 format.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are present in integrating various snow water equivalent datasets, and how might these affect the interpretation of climate and hydrological models?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating different snow water equivalent datasets presents challenges due to discrepancies in time ranges, spatial and temporal continuity, and accuracy. These differences can impact the dataset's quality, influencing the accuracy and reliability of climate and hydrological models. Addressing these challenges through data fusion techniques like machine learning can help mitigate such issues and provide more accurate data for interpreting climate and hydrological models.

Interpretation.Question: How do different spatial and temporal resolutions of snow water equivalent datasets impact the interpretation of data trends in hydrological and climate studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial and temporal resolutions of snow water equivalent datasets are critical for accurate interpretation in hydrological and climate studies. High-resolution datasets provide more detailed information, enabling precise analysis of snowmelt patterns and their effects on ecosystems and human activities. Variations in resolution can lead to different interpretations of data trends, emphasizing the need for datasets that balance resolution and coverage.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the discrepancies among existing SWE data products, and how might these factors affect data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There are great differences among remote sensing SWE, reanalysis SWE data, data assimilation SWE, and observational SWE. These discrepancies are influenced by varying spatial and temporal continuities, data integrity, and accuracy levels. The mean absolute error (MAE) of reanalysis SWE data is 0.65, indicating accuracy issues that can affect the data collection methods by necessitating more robust integration approaches to improve precision.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need to fuse multiple SWE datasets using machine learning algorithms, and what challenges does this address in data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Combining multiple SWE datasets using machine learning algorithms like ridge regression addresses the challenge of lacking temporal continuity and spatial resolution in individual SWE products. This approach helps to prepare SWE products with long time series and large spatial scales, retaining the advantages of each single SWE product while providing more accurate data for hydrological and climate models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limitations in the time ranges of SWE data products such as AMSR-E and AMSR-E2, and how does this impact dataset development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The time ranges of AMSR-E and AMSR-E2 SWE data are only from 2003 to the present, which limits their temporal series. This limitation is caused by the start dates of satellite missions and impacts dataset development by prompting the need for data fusion with other sources like reanalysis and assimilation datasets to create a seamless time series that can support long-term studies in hydrology and climate change.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the accuracy of snow water equivalent estimates when utilizing a ridge regression model that integrates multiple snow data sources?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The accuracy of the snow water equivalent estimates is improved by 28%, 22%, 37%, 11%, and 11% compared with the individual AMSR-E/AMSR2, ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, and ERA5-Land datasets, respectively. The method takes full advantage of each dataset and considers the altitude factor, leading to a more accurate and stable outcome.

Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of various existing SWE products using a machine learning algorithm, specifically the ridge regression model, aims to generate a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision SWE product. This is expected to provide more accurate SWE data for hydrological and climate models, thereby supporting studies on cryosphere change and climate change.

Goal Orientation.Answer: Creating an SWE dataset with long time series and large spatial scales is crucial because it retains the advantages of single SWE data products while addressing the limitations of existing datasets. A comprehensive dataset supports accurate estimation of snowmelt runoff impacts on ecosystems and human activities, which is significant for hydrometeorological and climate change research.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale behind using the ridge regression model for the fusion of SWE datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The ridge regression model is utilized for the fusion of SWE datasets because it improves the accuracy of the resulting SWE product compared to individual datasets. This approach effectively takes advantage of the strengths of each SWE dataset and considers factors like altitude, leading to a stable and scalable method for producing snow datasets on a global scale.

This method helps to create a new dataset that retains the advantages of each individual SWE data product while improving overall accuracy and spatial resolution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental methodologies for enhancing the temporal and spatial continuity of a snow water equivalent dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Enhancing temporal and spatial continuity can be achieved through the application of a ridge regression model that integrates various SWE datasets, including ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and ERA5-Land SWE data. This approach allows for the generation of a new dataset with improved accuracy, higher spatial resolution, and extended temporal coverage from 1979-2019.

Enablement.Question: What machine learning algorithms enable the integration of multiple sources of snow water equivalent (SWE) data to improve accuracy and spatial resolution?
Enablement.Answer: The ridge regression model (RRM) of a machine learning algorithm is used to integrate various existing SWE products, improving accuracy and spatial resolution by combining multiple data sources.

Enablement.Question: How do different spatial and temporal resolutions of snow water equivalent (SWE) datasets enable comprehensive hydrological and climate modeling?
Enablement.Answer: Different SWE datasets provide varying spatial resolutions (e.g., 25 km×25 km, 1°×1°, 0.25°×0.25°) and temporal resolutions (e.g., daily, 3-hourly, monthly), which enable comprehensive hydrological and climate modeling by offering data that can be adjusted to fit specific model requirements.

Enablement.Answer: The fusion of SWE datasets using machine learning algorithms enables better accuracy by leveraging the strengths of each dataset, accounting for spatial scales, and considering factors like altitude, which collectively improve data quality over individual datasets.

Judgmental.Question: How can machine learning algorithms like ridge regression improve the precision and reliability of snow water equivalent (SWE) datasets compared to traditional methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Machine learning algorithms, such as ridge regression, can improve the precision and reliability of snow water equivalent datasets by integrating various existing SWE products to generate a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision dataset. This approach takes full advantage of each SWE dataset and considers factors like altitude, leading to improved accuracy and higher spatial resolution compared to traditional methods.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges in achieving high accuracy and temporal continuity in snow water equivalent (SWE) data collection, and how might these be addressed through data fusion?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in achieving high accuracy and temporal continuity in SWE data collection include differences among existing SWE products, limited time ranges, and poor accuracy in some datasets. These challenges can be addressed through data fusion, which combines multiple datasets using techniques like machine learning ridge regression, to create SWE products with long time series and large spatial scales while retaining the advantages of single SWE data products.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can different original input datasets, such as ERA-Interim, GLDAS, and AMSR-E/AMSR2, be effectively combined to enhance the quality and applicability of snow water equivalent (SWE) datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Different original input datasets like ERA-Interim, GLDAS, and AMSR-E/AMSR2 can be effectively combined to enhance the quality and applicability of SWE datasets by utilizing machine learning models, such as ridge regression, to integrate these datasets. This approach leverages the strengths of each dataset, improves accuracy, increases spatial resolution, and produces a more comprehensive SWE dataset suitable for various hydrological and climate models.

Assertion.Answer: Utilizing a machine learning algorithm, specifically the ridge regression model, allows for the effective fusion of multiple existing SWE products. This approach integrates various datasets like ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and ERA5-Land to generate a high-precision SWE dataset with improved accuracy and spatial resolution.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in ensuring the temporal continuity and accuracy of snow water equivalent datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the limited time ranges of datasets like AMSR-E and AMSR-E2, which only cover from 2003 to the present, and the poor accuracy of reanalysis SWE data with a mean absolute error of 0.65. These issues highlight the differences among remote sensing, reanalysis, data assimilation, and observational SWE data, making it difficult to ensure both temporal continuity and accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why existing snow water equivalent datasets have such varying levels of quality and accuracy.
Assertion.Answer: The variation in quality and accuracy of SWE datasets arises from the diverse methodologies and data sources used, such as remote sensing, reanalysis, and data assimilation. Each has its strengths and weaknesses, with no single dataset excelling in all aspects. The differences in spatial and temporal resolutions, as well as the methodologies for data collection and processing, contribute to these variations.

Request/Directive.Answer: The use of a ridge regression model (RRM) based on a machine learning algorithm is effective for integrating various SWE datasets. This approach utilizes datasets such as ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and ERA5-Land SWE data, each with different spatial and temporal resolutions. The method focuses on overcoming the limitations of individual datasets by leveraging their strengths, resulting in improved accuracy and resolution of the fused SWE products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please assess the challenges faced in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of snow water equivalent (SWE) datasets when combining multiple sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: Combining multiple SWE datasets presents challenges such as differences in temporal range, spatial resolution, and inherent data quality. For instance, AMSR-E and AMSR-E2 datasets have limited time series, while reanalysis SWE data, although spatially and temporally continuous, suffer from accuracy issues with a mean absolute error of 0.65. These differences necessitate careful consideration during the fusion process to ensure accuracy and reliability of the resulting dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets or data assimilation techniques that could be utilized to enhance the quality of snow water equivalent (SWE) data products in climate and hydrological models.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for enhancing SWE data products include ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and ERA5-Land SWE data. Data assimilation techniques like machine learning-based ridge regression models could be used to fuse these datasets, considering factors such as spatial resolution and the integration of altitude data. This approach can lead to more precise SWE data, which is crucial for climate and hydrological models.
